author: @AsILetYouDie
text: For anyone wondering how (or too lazy) to implement the rounded edges for the buttons, here is my code (the variables have different names but you won't be lost) :  	if x < mouse[0] < x + width and y < mouse[1] < y + height : 		pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, active_color, (x + radius, y, width - radius * 2, height)) 		pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, active_color, (x, y + radius, width, height - radius * 2)) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, active_color, (x + radius, y + radius), radius) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, active_color, (x + width - radius, y + radius), radius) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, active_color, (x + radius, y + height - radius), radius) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, active_color, (x + width - radius, y + height - radius), radius) 		if click[0] == 1 and action != None: 			if action == "play": 				game_loop() 			elif action == "exit": 				pygame.quit() 				quit() 	else: 		pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, inactive_color, (x + radius, y, width - radius * 2, height)) 		pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, inactive_color, (x, y + radius, width, height - radius * 2)) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, inactive_color, (x + radius, y + radius), radius) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, inactive_color, (x + width - radius, y + radius), radius) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, inactive_color, (x + radius, y + height - radius), radius) 		pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, inactive_color, (x + width - radius, y + height - radius), radius)

author: @ahnafalhabib5430
text: For the click segment, I have an easier, more dynamic way of doing it, where you can use for any button. My Code is: ## Button Function def button(msg, x, y, w, h, i, a):      mouse = pygame.mouse.get_pos()      click = pygame.mouse.get_pressed()        if x + w > mouse[0] > x and y + h > mouse[1] > y:          c1 = a          if click[0] == 1:              clicked = True          else:              clicked = False      else:          c1 = i          clicked = False        pygame.draw.rect(win, c1, (x, y, w, h))        smallText = pygame.font.Font("freesansbold.ttf", 20)      textSurf, textRect = textObjects(msg, smallText)      textRect.center = ((x + (w / 2)), (y + (h / 2)))      win.blit(textSurf, textRect)        if clicked:          return True ## Inside Start Screen         x1, y1 = 250, 450          x2, y2 = 450, 450          w, h = 100, 50          Go = button("GO!", x1, y1, w, h, (0,200,0), (0,250,0))          Exit = button("Exit", x2, y2, w, h, (200,0,0), (250, 0, 0))            if Go:              main(clock)          elif Exit:              pygame.quit()              quit()

author: @jasondelong83
text: HOW TO FIX BROKEN GO BUTTON:  Go to your def game_loop():  def game_loop():     x = (display_width * 0.45)     y = (display_height * 0.8)     x_change = 0     thing_startx = random.randrange(0, display_width)     thing_starty = -600     thing_speed = 4     thing_width = 100     thing_height = 100     dodged = 0         gameExit = False     while not gameExit:         for event in pygame.event.get():             if event.type == pygame.QUIT:                 gameExit = True             print(event)            if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:             if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:                 x_change = -5         if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:             if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                 x_change = 5         if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:             if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:                 x_change = 0         if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:             if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                 x_change = 0          And fix the alignment of your if states in the following code by highlighting all of this code and pressing TAB so it moves one tab to the right. Fixed.         if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:             if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:                 x_change = -5         if event.type == pygame.KEYDOWN:             if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                 x_change = 5         if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:             if event.key == pygame.K_LEFT:                 x_change = 0         if event.type == pygame.KEYUP:             if event.key == pygame.K_RIGHT:                 x_change = 0  you're welcome

author: @Huguillon
text: I made a radious button, here the code in this tutorial: def radButton(radius, x, y, h, w, color):    pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, color, (x + radius, y + radius), radius)     pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, color, (x + radius, (y + h) - radius), radius)     pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, color, ((x + w) - radius, (y + h) - radius), radius)     pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, color, ((x + w) - radius, y + radius), radius)     pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, color, (x, y + radius, w, h - radius * 2))     pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, color, (x + radius, y, w - radius * 2, h))  def button(msg, x, y, w, h, ic, ac, action=None):     mouse = pygame.mouse.get_pos()     click = pygame.mouse.get_pressed()     radius = 12      if x+w+radius > mouse[0] > x-radius and y+h+radius > mouse[1] > y-radius:         radButton(radius, x, y, h, w, ac)         if click[0] == 1 and action != None:             action()     else:         radButton(radius, x, y, h, w, ic)

author: @bairfreedom
text: Ok, I did MUCH less to get my buttons to work.  I did not draw buttons using the pydraw function. I used paint and imported the images with their function already painted on. I also skipped the "def "button" business. Instead, after defining the measurements of where the buttons were,  I put in an "if" command under the button paremeters. So instead of saying "Nuclear Missles launched" I told it to "game_loop" on the start and pygame.quit quit() on the exit.  See below:           mouse = pygame.mouse.get_pos()         click = pygame.mouse.get_pressed()         #print(mouse)         #print(click)          if 250+130 > mouse[0] > 210 and 500+50 > mouse [1] > 450:             gamedisplay.blit(startbutton2, (214, 450, 100, 50))             if click[0]==1:                 game_loop()         else:             gamedisplay.blit(startbutton, (214, 450, 100, 50))         if 550+132 > mouse[0] > 500 and 515+50 > mouse[1] > 450:             gamedisplay.blit(exitbutton,  (500, 450, 100, 50))             if click[0]==1:                 pygame.quit()                 quit()         else:             gamedisplay.blit(exitbutton2, (500, 450, 100, 50))           pygame.display.update()

author: @razorproductions5609
text: This is the best script I was able to modify to near perfection. I used +Aaron Foster's and +sentdex combined scripting skills and my meticulous tendencies to make both's script work perfectly. Thanks to them you now have working buttons that have rounded edges.  def text_objects(text, font):     textSurface = font.render(text, True, black)     return textSurface, textSurface.get_rect()     def button(msg,x,y,w,h,ic,ac,action=None):     mouse = pygame.mouse.get_pos()     click = pygame.mouse.get_pressed()      if x+w > mouse[0] > x and y+h > mouse[1] > y:         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ac,(x,y,w,h))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.05*w), y), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.95*w), y), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.05*w), y+h), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.95*w), y+h), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ac, (x+.05*w,y-.045*w,.9*w,.05*w))         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ac, (x+.05*w,y+h,.9*w,.05*w))         if click[0] == 1 and action != None:             action()                               else:              pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ic,(x,y,w,h))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ic, (x+int(.05*w), y), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ic, (x+int(.95*w), y), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ic, (x+int(.05*w), y+h), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ic, (x+int(.95*w), y+h), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ic, (x+.05*w,y-.045*w,.9*w,.05*w))         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ic, (x+.05*w,y+h,.9*w,.05*w))                smallText = pygame.font.SysFont('comicsansms',20)     textSurf, text = text_objects(msg, smallText)     text.center = ( (x+(w/2)), (y+(h/2)) )     gameDisplay.blit(textSurf, text)

author: @EndTheFilms
text: Hey, so, I learned a ton from these tutorials, but im having some trouble. I decided to have differant difficulties to the game (I have a 'You won' screen, and wanted to have more options for the player) so I replaced the function for the 'GO' button so instead of it being game_loop, it is game_diff (my thing for choose the difficulty) Yet every time I click the button, it still takes me directly to the game, and not to the 'choose you difficulty' menu. Can anyone help? I am also having trouble with the 'Help' menu I got set up, I wanted the option to go back to the menu (the button was in the same place as the 'go' button on the main menu) and whenever I hit 'back' instead of taking me to the game_intro, it takes me to the game_loop.

author: @InertZero
text: I made rounded corners by drawing a circle near all four corners, and an additional rectangle on top and bottom.          pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.05*w), y), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.95*w), y), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.05*w), y+h), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.circle(gameDisplay, ac, (x+int(.95*w), y+h), int(.05*w))         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ac, (x+.05*w,y-.05*w,.9*w,.05*w))         pygame.draw.rect(gameDisplay, ac, (x+.05*w,y+h,.9*w,.05*w))  A little clunky, but it gets the job done.  Big thanks for these videos, I'm learning a ton about Python and game coding!

author: @KBibbler
text: I seem to have a problem.  Say if on my game_intro() screen I have a button that says "options", logically I'd have another subroutine called options_intro(). Now, on this screen I have two more buttons which are in the same location as the buttons on the game_intro() screen. What my problem is, is that whenever I press a button on the options_intro() screen, they seem to be following the instructions of the buttons on the game_intro() screen. It's like I'm clicking through the buttons to the lowest one (the game_intro() buttons). Any idea how to fix this?
